title: Clarification on chat API and chatProvider Proposal Support
body:

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->


I am trying to create a chat extension (@etlAgent) for the Copilot chat using the chat namespace and chatProvider proposal. However, I am encountering issues where the chat namespace and related types (e.g., ChatRequest, ChatContext, ChatResponseStream) are not recognized.

Steps Taken:
1. Enabled the chatProvider proposal in package.json:

```
"enabledApiProposals": [
    "chat",
    "chatProvider"
]
```

2. Implemented the createChatParticipant API in extension.ts:

```
const agent = vscode.chat.createChatParticipant(
    'etlAgent',
    async (request, chatContext, stream, token) => {
        ...
    }
);
```

3. Used the Insider version of VS Code (1.104.0-insider) and the latest vscode module (1.1.37).

Errors Encountered:

- Property 'chat' does not exist on type 'typeof import("vscode")'.
- Namespace '"vscode"' has no exported member 'ChatRequest'.
- Similar errors for ChatContext and ChatResponseStream.


Environment:

- VS Code Version: 1.104.0-insider
- vscode Module Version: 1.1.37
- Node.js Version: 22.17.0
- OS: macOS 24.6.0

Request: Could you confirm

1. If the chat API and chatProvider proposal are supported in the current setup?
2. If additional configuration or a specific vscode module version is required?
3. Any guidance on resolving the errors mentioned above?

Error:

```
npm run compile

etl-agent@0.0.1 compile
tsc -p ./

src/extension.ts:6:24 - error TS2339: Property 'chat' does not exist on type 'typeof import("vscode")'.
6   const agent = vscode.chat.createChatParticipant(
src/extension.ts:9:23 - error TS2694: Namespace '"vscode"' has no exported member 'ChatRequest'.
9       request: vscode.ChatRequest,
src/extension.ts:10:27 - error TS2694: Namespace '"vscode"' has no exported member 'ChatContext'.
10       chatContext: vscode.ChatContext,
src/extension.ts:11:22 - error TS2694: Namespace '"vscode"' has no exported member 'ChatResponseStream'.
11       stream: vscode.ChatResponseStream,

Found 4 errors in the same file, starting at: src/extension.ts:6
```

title: Add Ctrl+Shift+V toggle for Markdown preview/editor switching

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: markdown
labels.description: Markdown support issues

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
## Problem
The current markdown workflow has usability issues:

1. **Double-click interference**: Double-clicking in markdown preview (e.g., to select/copy text or follow links) switches back to editor view, which is disruptive when working extensively with markdown files and internal links.

2. **Missing return shortcut**: While `Ctrl+Shift+V` opens markdown preview, there's no default shortcut to return to the editor from preview mode.

3. **Tab clutter**: Having separate tabs for normal view and rendered view creates tab bloat, especially when working with multiple files.

## Current Workaround
I've disabled the double-click behavior with:
```json
"markdown.preview.doubleClickToSwitchToEditor": false
```

And created a custom keybinding:
```json
[
  {
    "key": "ctrl+shift+v",
    "command": "markdown.showEditor",
    "when": "activeEditor == 'workbench.editor.markdown.previewEditor'"
  }
]
```

## Proposed Solution
**Add `Ctrl+Shift+V` as a native toggle** between markdown preview and editor modes. This makes logical sense because:
- Same shortcut works both ways (no confusion)
- No conflict when in preview mode (the shortcut isn't used there)
- Intuitive toggle behavior users expect

## Additional Considerations
The dual-tab approach feels outdated compared to modern markdown editors. A **single-file view with optional rendered overlay** would be more elegant, though I understand this might be a larger architectural change.

## Impact
This simple addition would significantly improve the markdown workflow in VS Code, making it competitive with dedicated markdown editors while maintaining VS Code's strengths.

title: Add apply changes button to chat multi-diff content part with precise diff application
body:
This PR adds a new "Apply Changes to Workspace" button to the chat multi-diff content part that allows users to directly apply suggested file changes from chat responses to their workspace files using precise diff computation.

## Problem
Users viewing multi-file diffs in chat responses had to manually copy and apply changes to their workspace files. There was no direct way to apply the suggested changes, making the workflow cumbersome.

## Solution
Added a new button with a check icon (✓) next to the existing "View All File Changes" button that:

- Uses VS Code's native `IDiffProviderFactoryService` to compute precise line-level diffs between original and modified content
- Converts computed diffs to targeted `TextEdit` operations using `DetailedLineRangeMapping.toTextEdit()`
- Applies only the specific changed portions rather than replacing entire files
- Creates workspace edits targeting the actual workspace files using VS Code's bulk edit service
- Shows success/error notifications to provide user feedback

## Implementation Details

The implementation leverages VS Code's existing diff infrastructure, following patterns from the git extension:

- **Precise diff computation**: Uses `IDiffProviderFactoryService` with advanced diff algorithm to calculate exact changes
- **Surgical edits**: Converts diffs to targeted text edits that modify only changed lines, not entire files
- **Resource management**: Creates temporary text models for diff computation and properly cleans them up
- **Error handling**: Gracefully handles missing files, read failures, and bulk edit failures with user notifications
- **Proper localization**: All user-facing strings are localized

The button handles both existing files (applies precise changes) and new files, using `ResourceTextEdit` with computed diff operations. This approach is much more efficient and accurate than wholesale file replacement.

## Screenshot
![Apply Changes Button](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/4af6bc62-1790-4014-9ed1-3f47a1760854)

The new button appears between the "View All File Changes" button (⟤) and any contributed buttons, providing a seamless way for users to apply chat-suggested changes directly to their workspace with surgical precision.

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->

Version: 1.103.0 (Universal)
Commit: e3550cfac4b63ca4eafca7b601f0d2885817fd1f
Date: 2025-08-06T21:40:10.271Z
Electron: 37.2.3
ElectronBuildId: 12035395
Chromium: 138.0.7204.100
Node.js: 22.17.0
V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0
OS: Darwin x64 24.6.0

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create **workspace-specific** terminal profile in `.vscode/settings.json` that loads `.bash_profile` with shell functions and aliases which are specific to the project:
  ```json
  {
    "terminal.integrated.defaultProfile.osx": "bash",
    "terminal.integrated.profiles.osx": {
      "bash": {
        "path": "/usr/local/bin/bash",
        "args": ["--rcfile", ".vscode/.bash_profile"],
        "icon": "terminal-bash"
      }
    }
  }
  ```
  _It doesn't really matter what `.vscode/.bash_profile` contains. A simple alias will demonstrate the issue._

2. Open a new integrated terminal window. The shell should be sourced with the contents of `.vscode/.bash_profile`. This can also be verified:
  ```bash
  $ ps auxw | grep '\b'$$'\b'
  erhhung  19604  0.0  0.0 34884824  21348 s013  Ss  4:03PM  0:01.87 /usr/local/bin/bash --rcfile .vscode/.bash_profile
  ```

3. Restart VSCode (or when prompted to restart for upgrade).

4. VSCode restores all previously opened windows, including workspace tabs and integrated terminal sessions. However, restored terminal sessions that were previously launched using a workspace-specific profile are no longer relaunched using that profile:

  ```bash
  $ ps auxw | grep '\b'$$'\b'
  erhhung  15265  1.7  0.0 35448024  22040 s009  Ss  3:50PM  0:03.20 /usr/local/bin/bash -l
  ```
  The restored terminal session was instead launched using the **global** terminal profile, which lacks the additional shell functions and aliases needed for that workspace.

Version: 1.103.2
Commit: 6f17636121051a53c88d3e605c491d22af2ba755
Date: 2025-08-20T16:45:34.255Z
Electron: 37.2.3
ElectronBuildId: 12035395
Chromium: 138.0.7204.100
Node.js: 22.17.0
V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0
OS: Linux x64 6.14.0-27-generic

Steps to Reproduce:

I'm sure this has been reported before in various other bugs, but I couldn't find anything that specifically addressed the very frequent problems I have with auto-indentation, both with typing and pasted text.  It just feels like the auto-indent feature is just fundamentally broken.  I'll be using this bug to report all of the instances of bad indentation in vscode.

I have the following C code:

```
	if (func && nvkm_wr32_trace) {
		if ((a == NV04_PTIMER_TIME_0) || (a == NV04_PTIMER_TIME_1)) {
			if ((nvkm_rd32_value != v) || (nvkm_rd32_address != a))
				printk(KERN_ERR
				       "%s::%u rd32 0x%08x <- 0x%08x\n",
				       func, line, v, a);
			nvkm_rd32_value = v;
			nvkm_rd32_address = a;

	}
```

As you can see, a } is missing from the second-to-last line.  I put my cursor in column 1 of that line, and press }.  I expect the } to be placed in the same column as the "i" in "if ((a == NV04_PTIMER_TIME_0)".  But this is where vscode actually puts it:

```
			nvkm_rd32_address = a;
				}
	}
```

There is no style guideline where that position would ever make sense.  vscode is obviously confused by the fact the inner if-statement has no parentheses.

As I discover more inconsistencies, I will post them here.

I didn't realize the AI statistics were per-project, so when I switched to a new project, I was confused why my stats went to 0.

A few thoughts:

title: Fix keyboard trap in MCP "New Tools" button by adding keyboard event handling
body:
The MCP "New Tools" button in the chat interface was creating a keyboard trap where users could tab to the button but couldn't navigate away from it using the keyboard. This particularly affected screen reader users and those relying on keyboard navigation.

## Root Cause
The button was created using the `h()` DOM helper but only handled mouse click events. It was missing proper keyboard event handlers for Enter and Space keys, which are standard activation keys for buttons according to accessibility guidelines.

## Solution
Added keyboard event handling to the MCP button that:
- Responds to Enter and Space keys for button activation
- Allows Tab and other navigation keys to work normally 
- Uses VS Code's standard `StandardKeyboardEvent` and `KeyCode` classes
- Shares the same action logic between mouse and keyboard interactions

The fix ensures the button behaves like a proper accessible button while maintaining all existing functionality.

## Technical Changes
- Added imports for `StandardKeyboardEvent` and `KeyCode`
- Added `KEY_DOWN` event listener that handles Enter/Space activation
- Refactored action logic into shared `executeAction()` method
- Only prevents default behavior for activation keys, not navigation keys

This resolves the accessibility issue while following established VS Code patterns for keyboard interaction.

Fixes #262332.

title: Honor workbench.externalBrowser setting for GitHub issue creation
body:
The "Create bug on GitHub" button was not respecting the `workbench.externalBrowser` setting, always opening URLs in the system default browser instead of the user's configured preference.

## Problem

When users clicked the "Create bug on GitHub" button in the issue reporter, the implementation used direct window opening methods:
- `dom.windowOpenNoOpener()` in the browser version
- `mainWindow.open()` for dynamically created GitHub issues

These methods bypassed VS Code's external browser configuration, forcing users to use their system default browser even when they had configured a different browser via `workbench.externalBrowser`.

## Solution

Replaced direct window opening with `IOpenerService`, which properly respects the external browser setting:

**Before:**
```typescript
dom.windowOpenNoOpener(uri);
mainWindow.open(result.html_url, '_blank');
```

**After:**
```typescript
this.openerService.open(uri, { openExternal: true });
this.openerService.open(result.html_url, { openExternal: true });
```

## Changes

- **BrowserIssueService**: Added `IOpenerService` injection and replaced `dom.windowOpenNoOpener()` calls
- **BaseIssueReporterService**: Added `IOpenerService` injection and replaced `mainWindow.open()` calls  
- **IssueWebReporter & IssueReporter**: Updated constructors to pass `IOpenerService` to base class
- All implementations now use `openerService.open(url, { openExternal: true })` for consistent behavior

## Testing

Added unit tests to verify `IOpenerService` is called with the correct parameters and options.

This change ensures that both the legacy GitHub issue reporter (when `issueReporter.experimental.webReporter` is false) and the new web-based issue reporter honor the user's browser preference configured via `workbench.externalBrowser`.

Fixes #260950.

title: Fix CSS selector mismatch for confirmation button hiding
body:
The confirmation buttons were not being hidden when `setShowButtons(false)` was called due to a CSS selector mismatch with the actual DOM structure. ## Problem When calling `setShowButtons(false)` on chat confirmation widgets, the `hideButtons` class was being applied to the `.chat-confirmation-widget-container` element, but the CSS rules were targeting `.chat-confirmation-widget.hideButtons` and `.chat-confirmation-widget2.hideButtons`. This created a selector mismatch where the CSS rules could not find their target elements. The DOM structure shows: ```html
...
...
``` But the CSS was looking for: ```css .chat-confirmation-widget2.hideButtons .chat-confirmation-widget-buttons ``` ## Solution Updated the CSS selectors to correctly target the DOM hierarchy where the `hideButtons` class is actually applied: - `.chat-confirmation-widget.hideButtons .chat-buttons-container` → `.chat-confirmation-widget-container.hideButtons .chat-buttons-container` - `.chat-confirmation-widget2.hideButtons .chat-confirmation-widget-buttons` → `.chat-confirmation-widget-container.hideButtons .chat-confirmation-widget-buttons` - `.chat-confirmation-widget2.hideButtons .chat-toolbar-container` → `.chat-confirmation-widget-container.hideButtons .chat-toolbar-container` This ensures that both the old and new confirmation widget types properly hide their buttons when the `hideButtons` class is applied to the container element. Fixes #263475. > [!WARNING] > >

title: Request to add Composio MCP to VS Code MCP Server Listings
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Hello VS Code team,

I noticed that the [official VS Code MCP servers page](https://code.visualstudio.com/mcp)
 currently lists only a limited set of MCP servers. I’d like to request the addition of [Composio MCP](https://mcp.composio.dev/)
 to the catalog.

Why Composio MCP?

✅ Provides a large collection of MCP servers out of the box.

✅ Built on top of the official MCP SDKs (@modelcontextprotocol/sdk for JS/TS and mcp for Python).

✅ Widely adopted in the MCP ecosystem for connecting tools, APIs, and services into editors like VS Code and Continue.dev.

✅ Actively maintained, with extensive documentation and community support.

Benefit to VS Code users:
Adding Composio MCP to the official list will give developers immediate access to a broad range of integrations (APIs, tools, workflows) without needing to configure each one manually. This improves the out-of-the-box MCP experience in VS Code.

Reference:

Composio MCP website: https://mcp.composio.dev/

GitHub repo (if applicable): https://github.com/composiohq/composio

Request:
Please consider adding Composio MCP to the official MCP server listings on [code.visualstudio.com/mcp](https://code.visualstudio.com/mcp)
.

Thank you for your great work on MCP support in VS Code! 🙌

body:
Type: Bug This report generated from another AI that I have tasked to drive your Claude Agent. I asked it to create a specific block of code that would capture and output the seed values for each randomizer in a workflow. Claude incorrectly told me that it did, implying the node would provide all necessary metadata as per the request. In reality, the code claude made only outputs basic metadata (timestamp, trigger, module list) and does not extract or serialize any of the specifically requested items. Claude continued on swearing that the code had the functionality for a long time. Even after having antother AI evaluate the code block it swears it is in the right. Deepseek and OpenAI 4.o disagree with claude and I do too. This misinformation led to lost time and a very angry developer who isnt very likely to spend more money on your products without some SERIOUS fixes to this degenerative ai. Summary: Claude’s mistake was claiming the code captured a bunch of data, when it only caught generic metadata. This led to wasted time and a very angry developer. At this point I am certain that your bot makes mistakes so you can sell more tokens. I'd like mine refunded for this heap. title: fix: parse commands in chat.open commands
body:
`workbench.action.chat.open` did not always trigger a parse of the input resulting in `/<prompt>` not being recognized as a prompt command when it's expected to.

If `isPartialQuery: false` (default), then the command used [`acceptInput` intead of `setInput`](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/709b8fabf55c505cbe5603ce654ecf3a8766a7a6/src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/actions/chatActions.ts#L244) only the latter of which will trigger a [re-parse of the query](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/709b8fabf55c505cbe5603ce654ecf3a8766a7a6/src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/chatWidget.ts#L1640) to critcially turn [`/<prompt>` into a `ChatRequestSlashPromptPart`](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/d2ff8d16065d4748b8a205bfebdc98d7d76f7864/src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/common/chatRequestParser.ts#L231).

**Reviewers**: There's a few places `acceptInput` is called with a query in the codebase. It's not clear to me if the others have the same issue or if always triggering a re-parse would double parse.

title: Suggestion: Enable Copilot Chat to Generate Interactive Controls for User Choices
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

In my recent development practice using VS Code with Copilot, I’ve noticed something important. Models like ChatGPT-5 often take the initiative to ask users clarifying or guiding questions. This proactive behavior is a significant milestone in AI, because it shows that the model is capable of driving conversations toward deeper goals.

As we know, achieving meaningful outcomes often requires abstraction-to-concrete transitions, and proactive questioning is crucial in that process. For example, when the AI recognizes that its current understanding of the context is incomplete, it might ask follow-up questions, or when it thinks the user could provide more detail, it prompts for clarification. This is excellent, and I believe Copilot should evolve further in this direction.

Currently, Copilot Chat in VS Code works well in text-based interactions—users can type their replies freely. However, many of these AI questions could be better served through direct user choices. For example, when the AI presents options, why not allow Copilot Chat to render interactive controls (e.g., selection boxes, toggles, or other UI elements) directly inside the conversation? The user could then select an option and submit it, which would be faster and more convenient than typing.

This is just an inspiration, not a strict proposal—interactive elements could go beyond simple selection boxes. But I believe this would significantly enhance usability and help Copilot lead users more effectively through complex topics.

title: Support all chatSessionTypes in registerGroupListeners and enable local view to track all sessions
body:
## Problem

The `registerGroupListeners` method in `chatSessions.ts` had two key limitations:

1. **Limited session type support**: Only detected chat editors with the 'local' session type and showed them in the local chat sessions view
2. **Isolated provider notifications**: Only the specific session type provider was notified when editors opened/closed, preventing cross-provider visibility

This meant that chat editors using `vscode-chat-session` URIs with custom session types (like `github-copilot`, `external-provider`, etc.) were not being tracked or displayed properly, and users couldn't see new editors with different providers in the local view until they sent requests.

## Root Cause

The original implementation had several limitations:

1. **Restrictive scheme filtering**: Only accepted `vscode-chat-editor` scheme URIs
2. **Hardcoded session type**: Only supported the 'local' session type  
3. **Limited provider notification**: Only the matching provider was notified of editor changes
4. **Isolated session tracking**: Local provider only tracked sessions with 'local' session type

## Solution

### 1. Generalized Chat Session Detection

Updated the session detection logic to support both URI schemes and extract session types properly:

```typescript
// Before: Only vscode-chat-editor scheme
if (editor.resource?.scheme !== 'vscode-chat-editor') {
    return false;
}

// After: Support both schemes  
if (editor.resource?.scheme !== 'vscode-chat-editor' && 
    editor.resource?.scheme !== 'vscode-chat-session') {
    return false;
}
```

### 2. Session Type Extraction

Added logic to determine the correct session type from multiple sources with proper priority:

1. Explicit `chatSessionType` in editor options
2. Session type from `vscode-chat-session` URI authority
3. Default to 'local' for `vscode-chat-editor` scheme

### 3. Centralized Editor Tracking

Moved editor tracking from `LocalChatSessionsProvider` to `ChatSessionsView` to handle all session types globally. This ensures that when any chat editor opens, the appropriate provider gets notified based on the editor's session type.

### 4. Enhanced Provider Notification System

- Added `notifySessionItemsChanged(chatSessionType: string)` method to `IChatSessionsService`
- **Cross-provider notifications**: When any non-local chat editor opens/closes, both the specific provider AND the local provider get notified
- This enables the local view to track all active chat sessions regardless of their session type

### 5. Universal Local Session Tracking

Modified `LocalChatSessionsProvider.isLocalChatSession()` to track ALL chat sessions, not just those with 'local' session type. This allows users to see all their active chat editors in the local view, including those from other providers that haven't sent requests yet.

## Behavior Changes

**Before**: 
- Only `vscode-chat-editor` URIs with 'local' session type were tracked
- Custom session type editors only appeared in their specific provider views

**After**: 
- All chat session types are properly detected and routed to their appropriate views
- All active chat editors appear in BOTH their specific provider view AND the local view
- Users can see new editors with custom session types in the local view immediately, even before sending requests

## Example Usage

```typescript
// Local sessions (existing behavior preserved)
const localUri = URI.parse('vscode-chat-editor://session1');
// → Routes to local chat sessions view only

// Custom session types (enhanced behavior)  
const customUri = ChatSessionUri.forSession('github-copilot', 'session123');
// → Routes to github-copilot chat sessions view AND appears in local view

// Explicit session type in options (enhanced behavior)
const options: IChatEditorOptions = { chatSessionType: 'custom-provider' };
// → Routes to custom-provider chat sessions view AND appears in local view
```

## Backward Compatibility

- Existing 'local' chat sessions continue to work unchanged
- No breaking changes to existing APIs
- All current functionality preserved while adding new capabilities

## Testing

Added comprehensive unit tests covering:
- URI scheme detection for both supported schemes
- Session type extraction from various sources
- Provider notification system functionality
- Cross-provider session visibility
- Edge cases and backward compatibility scenarios

This change enables extensions to contribute custom chat session types that properly appear in their designated views when editors open, while also making all chat sessions visible in the local view for better user experience and discoverability.

---

title: Find history does not work as a most recent stack

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: Type: Feature Request When you use Find in VS Code, the search box keeps a history of what you’ve searched for. This is really helpful when working with things like Unicode characters, since I often need to search for Braille patterns (U+2800–U+28FF). Typing or pasting them each time takes extra steps, so being able to arrow through the history is a big time-saver. Here’s the problem: Let’s say two days ago I searched for the character ⠿ (U+283F). If I open Find and press the up arrow, it might take me 50 presses to get back to that entry. That makes sense the first time because the history is in chronological order. But if I then search for ⠿ again today, VS Code still keeps it way back in the list. So two hours later, if I want it again, I still have to arrow up those same 50 times. How other editors handle this: In some editors, the search history is treated like a "most recently used" list. That means once I search for ⠿ again, it moves closer to the top of the stack. So the next time I hit Find, I’d only need one or two up arrows to get back to it, not 50. Example: • Day 1: Search for ⠿ → 50 up arrows needed. • Day 2: Search for ⠿ again. • In VS Code → still 50 up arrows. • In other editors → only 1–2 up arrows, because it was bumped to the top. This difference makes the history in VS Code much less useful for repeated searches. To fix this the find history list should work as a most recent stack If I arrow up 50 times and select something that something should be moved to the head of the list. If the old search history method is desired by some then make this a find setting to change the find from true history to most recent search stack. VS Code version: Code 1.103.2 (6f17636121051a53c88d3e605c491d22af2ba755, 2025-08-20T16:45:34.255Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.19045 Modes:

body:
The default setting for `debug.openDebug` is `openOnDebugBreak` which I interpret to mean only when debugging breaks, however it seems to always be immediately shown when I start the first debug session.

Here, I have just reloaded the window, and the instant I click "Start Debugging" it switches to the debug sidebar.

I do want the debug sidebar to be shown when I hit a breakpoint, but I don't want it to be shown the first time I launch a debug session (that's what I assume the `openOnFirstSessionStart` does).

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.70.2
- OS Version: Windows 7 Service Pack 1 (Build 7601.27769)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install version 1.70.2 of VS Code

This “bug” has nothing to do with the VS Code project itself, but I couldn't find any other way to give feedback on the issue.

Users can only download version 1.70.2 from the official website with VS Code: https://code.visualstudio.com/updates/v1_70

And version 1.70.2 of VS Code cannot be updated because the update link is not working.

```
curl -H "User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Code/1.70.2 Chrome/100.0.4896.160 Electron/18.3.5 Safari/537.36" https://update.code.visualstudio.com/api/update/win32-x64/stable/e4503b30fc78200f846c62cf8091b76ff5547662
{"url":"https://az764295.vo.msecnd.net/stable/a21a160d630530476218b85db95b0fd2a8cd1230/VSCodeSetup-x64-1.70.3.exe","name":"1.70.3","version":"a21a160d630530476218b85db95b0fd2a8cd1230","productVersion":"1.70.3","hash":"3cb83ae9362dd88a03177ceaa86f99da3edb8d8b","timestamp":1661933349956,"sha256hash":"63a0e5beb949cbf70a8e8e78a8f2d0d8be48e6f59966769789f236fb7643711c","supportsFastUpdate":true}
```

`az764295.vo.msecnd.net` is long gone. I don't know why you didn't migrate the download server for version 1.70.3 to `vscode.download.prss.microsoft.com`.

I know that the best strategy is to update the system to Windows 10 or Windows 11, which has not yet finished its life cycle. but that's a business environment and it's not up to me.

title: Selecting a previous chat that has been disposed will lock the chat to be unable to switch to another chat session or to type any messages
Support org governed mcp registry endpoint and access restrictions
body: @connor4312 - While adopting to org governed mcp server access restrictions, I have intrdouced a new mcp access setting - `chat.mcp.access`. I have deprecated/removed the existing `chat.mcp.enabled` setting in favour of this.
